user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 is: A function parameter should not be modified.
Note that the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not be modified.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_ConsoleCreate_Impl:
```c
int32 OS_ConsoleCreate_Impl(const OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    OS_impl_console_internal_record_t *local;
    OS_console_internal_record_t *     console;
    pthread_t                          consoletask;
    int32                              return_code;
    OS_VoidPtrValueWrapper_t           local_arg = {0};

    console = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_console_table, *token);
    local   = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_impl_console_table, *token);

    if (token->obj_idx == 0)
    {
        return_code = OS_SUCCESS;

        if (console->IsAsync)
        {
            if (sem_init(&local->data_sem, 0, 0) < 0)
            {
                return_code = OS_SEM_FAILURE;
            }
            else
            {
                /* cppcheck-suppress unreadVariable // intentional use of other union member */
                local_arg.id = OS_ObjectIdFromToken(token);
                return_code  = OS_Posix_InternalTaskCreate_Impl(&consoletask, OS_CONSOLE_TASK_PRIORITY, 0,
                                                               OS_ConsoleTask_Entry, local_arg.opaque_arg);

                if (return_code != OS_SUCCESS)
                {
                    sem_destroy(&local->data_sem);
                }
            }
        }
    }
    else
    {
        /* only one physical console device is implemented */
        return_code = OS_ERR_NOT_IMPLEMENTED;
    }

    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_ConsoleCreate_Impl:
#define OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(tbl, tok) (&tbl[OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(&(tok))])
...
typedef struct OS_object_token OS_object_token_t
...
extern OS_console_internal_record_t OS_console_table[OS_MAX_CONSOLES]
...
OS_impl_console_internal_record_t OS_impl_console_table[OS_MAX_CONSOLES]
...
static inline osal_index_t OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(const OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    return token->obj_idx;
}
...
static inline osal_id_t OS_ObjectIdFromToken(const OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    return token->obj_id;
}
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: No code fragments in OS_ConsoleCreate_Impl modify the parameter pointer 'token' or the object it points to. All uses of 'token' are read-only: token->obj_idx and token are passed to inline accessors (OS_ObjectIndexFromToken, OS_ObjectIdFromToken) that take a const pointer and only read fields. The OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET macro is invoked with *token; inside the macro it takes the address (&(tok)), which becomes &(*token) and does not alter the pointer or the pointed object. There are no assignments to 'token' (e.g. token = ...), no pointer arithmetic on 'token', and no writes through 'token' (e.g. *token = ...). Also, 'token' is declared as a pointer to const, so any attempt to modify the pointed object or the pointer would be a compile-time error. Therefore no fragments require further investigation for MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8.
